awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Politics of Victimhood
awd_abstract_narration:
As of February 2018, there were 8.6 million registered victims of the Colombian armed conflict. This means that roughly one in six Colombians is recognized by the state as a victim of violence. This project proposes an investigation into the politics of victimhood in Colombia?s transitional context: Why are some victim claims seen as more legitimate than others in the eyes of the state, human rights actors, and conflict-affected individuals? How does the state produce the category of victim through its bureaucratic processes and how must conflict-affected individuals perform it in order to receive recognition and access benefits? And what are the implications of these constructed hierarchies for theories and experiences of justice during transitions from violence? These questions apply not only to the Colombian peace process, but also to justice dilemmas that arise in transitions from armed conflict worldwide.

Through interviews and discourse analysis, the project aims to understand how different actors who influence conflict-affected individuals? experiences of justice make sense of their power. Ethnographic observation will shed light on what the status of ?victim? means to those who vie for it or refuse it. It will also examine what individuals have to do to become recognizable as victims in the eyes of the law and the state. The goal of this inquiry into the evolution of the status of victims as political actors is not to reify this category, but to interrogate it and explore its political use by various actors during transitions from violence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Overview

As of February 2018, there were 8.6 million registered victims of the Colombian armed conflict. This means that roughly one in six Colombians is recognized by the state as a victim of violence. This project proposes an investigation into the politics of victimhood in Colombia’s transitional context: Why are some victim claims seen as more legitimate than others in the eyes of the state, human rights actors, and conflict-affected individuals? How does the state produce the category of victim through its bureaucratic processes and how must conflict-affected individuals perform it in order to receive recognition and access benefits? And what are the implications of these constructed hierarchies for theories and experiences of justice during transitions from violence? These questions apply not only to the Colombian peace process, but also to justice dilemmas that arise in transitions from armed conflict worldwide.

Completed Activities

The main research activities for this project consisted of interviews and life histories, ethnographic observation, and discourse analysis. I conducted 157 interviews with representatives of the Colombian state, victims’ associations, human rights defenders, and other key stakeholders. I also observed multiple events relevant to my research in the regions of Cundinamarca, Antioquia, and Meta. Illustratively, these events have included the Congressional Oversight Meeting for the Implementation of the Victims’ Law (June 2018), commemorative events associated with Victims’ Day (May 2018), a meeting of the commissioners of the Commission for the Clarification of Truth with representatives of victims’ associations in Antioquia (March 2018), and numerous meetings of Mesas de Participación de Víctimas (February-July 2018), which are forums for victim participation in politics. Collectively, the interviews, life histories, and observations have yielded over a thousand pages of fieldnotes. 

I analyzed this data inductively, paying attention to patterns that emerged from the research, and coded the interviews using the qualitative data coding software Dedoose. I then developed five draft dissertation chapters based on the analyzed data. These include an analysis of the ethics and methods of researching victimhood, an exploration of the lives of bureaucrats who work in mechanisms of transition justice, a discussion of the labor of victimhood, an investigation of how transitional justice bureaucracies engage with structural violence, and an inquiry into the future of the victim category in Colombia. The above chapters have been submitted to my PhD supervisors for feedback. I will incorporate this feedback and submit a revised, complete dissertation for defense in the 2019-2020 academic year. In addition to the dissertation-specific outputs, I developed two journal articles (under review), a book review, and a working paper based on this research.

In addition to these research, analysis, and write-up activities, I had the pleasure of disseminating preliminary findings at numerous academic conferences and workshops. These were instrumental both for sharing insights from this research and for receiving feedback that may strengthen the project.

Intended Outcomes

In terms of intellectual contributions, the project seeks to make two interventions in the understanding of victimhood during transitions of violence within the fields of the anthropology of suffering, peace and conflict studies, and transitional justice. First, it conteststhe perception of victimhood as a passive status or as a monolithic, universal category by tracing the performances different actors must produce in order to achieve legibility as victims. In doing so, it sheds light not on the violence of the war itself, but on the violence of the distinctions in its aftermath. Second, the project highlights victimhood as a form of citizenship, a type of currency, and a site of power. It, therefore, challenges framings of victimhood that are merely bureaucratic or exclusively legal and, instead, examines the ways in which bureaucracy and the law shape claim-making, relationships, and politics during transitions from violence.       

In terms of broader impacts, the first key implication of this project is to invite peace-builders and transitional justice practitioners to not treat ‘victim’ as synonymous to having suffered harm, thus hiding the labor involved in securing this recognition. Relatedly, the project draws attention to how referring to ‘the victims’ as a collective noun obscures the ways in which the category is heterogeneous and fragmented. Second, in the case of Colombia and beyond, receiving recognition as a victim can entitle individuals to financial compensation, inclusion in peace negotiations or political processes after peace agreements, and participation in memory initiatives. It is, therefore, essential to understand how the status of victim can become a site of contestation and the politics of inclusion in this category. Finally, through disseminating findings of this project among the state agencies that serve as sites for ethnographic observations and interviews, this research can shed light on how bureaucracies shape claim-making and how individuals’ legal and bureaucratic transactions in the aftermath of violence can represent a form of continued violation during transitions to peace.
